meta.title: Building This Portfolio
meta.subtitle: A meta case study on creating a role-agnostic portfolio with AI-forward workflows
meta.teaser: How I designed a format-based navigation system to present work across Content Design, Technical Writing, and Narrative roles—and built it using AI-assisted development.

project.summary: This case study explores the decisions behind building this portfolio site. As a multidisciplinary writer spanning Content Design, Technical Writing, and Narrative/Game Writing, I needed a portfolio structure that could adapt to different hiring contexts without pigeonholing my work into a single specialty. I also used this project as an opportunity to document my AI-forward development workflow.

section.heading: The Challenge
section.body:
Most portfolio sites are built around a single professional identity: "UX Writer," "Technical Writer," or "Content Designer." But my career has never fit neatly into one box. I've written API documentation at AWS, designed in-game reporting systems at Everland, produced live shows for Twitch streamers, and published tabletop game rulebooks.

The challenge was threefold:

  1. Present diverse work without confusion. A hiring manager looking for a Content Designer shouldn't have to wade through fiction samples, but a game studio should be able to find them easily.
  2. Avoid the "jack of all trades" perception. Range is an asset, but only if the portfolio demonstrates depth in each area.
  3. Build something maintainable. I needed a system where adding new work wouldn't require restructuring the entire site.

Traditional portfolio templates—organized by role or industry—would have forced visitors to pick a lane before exploring. I needed a different approach.

section.heading: Information Architecture: Format Over Role
section.body:
The key insight was organizing by format rather than role. Instead of categories like "UX Writing" or "Technical Documentation," I created two primary buckets:

Case Studies

Deep dives into content decisions based on specific objectives. These showcase cross-collaboration, strategic thinking, and measurable outcomes. They answer: "How do you approach complex problems?"

Individual Samples

Focused pieces demonstrating craft in a particular format without full project context. These answer: "Can you write in this specific style?"

This distinction is about depth and presentation style, not professional specialty. A case study about an in-game reporting system lives alongside one about API documentation. An individual sample of rulebook writing lives alongside one showcasing product documentation.

Why this works: Hiring managers can quickly find the depth they need. Looking for someone who thinks strategically about content systems? Case Studies. Need to verify someone can write clear API references? Individual Samples. The format-first approach lets my work speak for itself without forcing a professional identity onto the visitor.

section.heading: Technical Choice: Why XML Over Markdown
section.body:
Most static site generators default to Markdown for content. I chose XML instead, and here's why:

Structured Data, Not Just Text

Each project isn't just prose—it's structured data with metadata (tags, client, role, thumbnail), a summary, multiple sections, and outcomes. XML makes this structure explicit and enforceable. With Markdown, I'd need frontmatter for metadata and hope I remembered all the fields each time.

Validation

XML schemas (XSD files) let me validate content before it breaks the build. If I forget a required field or misname a tag, the validator catches it. Markdown has no equivalent—errors only surface when the page looks wrong.

AI-Friendly

When working with AI assistants like Claude, XML's explicit structure makes it easier to generate, modify, and validate content. The AI can work with a clear schema rather than inferring structure from formatting conventions.

Separation of Concerns

Content lives in XML. Presentation lives in templates (Nunjucks). Styling lives in CSS. This separation means I can completely redesign the site's appearance without touching content files.

Example: Project XML Structure

<project>
  <meta>
    <id>project-slug</id>
    <title>Project Title</title>
    <tags>
      <tag>Content Design</tag>
      <tag>Case Study</tag>
    </tags>
  </meta>
  <summary>Brief overview</summary>
  <content>
    <section>
      <heading>Section Title</heading>
      <body><![CDATA[HTML content here]]></body>
    </section>
  </content>
  <outcomes>
    <outcome>Key result</outcome>
  </outcomes>
</project>

section.heading: AI-Forward Development Workflow
section.body:
I built this entire site using Claude as a development partner. This wasn't about replacing my skills—it was about augmenting them. Here's how the collaboration worked:

Problem-Solving in Natural Language

When the tag filtering system wasn't updating correctly, I described the behavior I was seeing. Claude helped me trace the issue to a JavaScript event listener that wasn't properly scoped. Instead of spending hours debugging, we solved it in minutes through conversation.

Context Documents

I created detailed context files (context.md, TAG-SYSTEM.md, BLOG_IMPLEMENTATION_CONTEXT.md) that explain the architecture, coding standards, and common issues. These serve two purposes:

  1. They help Claude understand the codebase quickly in each session
  2. They serve as documentation for my future self

Iterative Refinement

The "Coming Soon" notice you see on placeholder pages went through several iterations. I described what I wanted ("a high visibility container with an SVG icon"), Claude implemented it, I gave feedback ("make the SVG yellow"), and we refined until it matched my vision. This feedback loop is faster than writing CSS from scratch.

What AI Can't Do

AI excelled at implementation but couldn't make content decisions. Which projects to feature? How to frame my career narrative? What tone to strike? Those decisions remained mine. The AI was a skilled collaborator, not an autopilot.

section.heading: Navigation Design: Tags for Discovery, Categories for Wayfinding
section.body:
The site uses two complementary navigation systems:

Tag Filtering (Desktop Only)

On desktop, a collapsible filter panel lets visitors narrow projects by up to 5 tags. Tags use AND logic—selecting "Content Design" and "GenAI" shows only projects with both tags. This supports exploratory browsing: "Show me everything involving AI."

Category Navigation (All Devices)

The sidebar organizes work into Case Studies, Individual Samples, and Content History. This supports directed browsing: "I want to see a full case study."

Why Tags Are Desktop-Only

On mobile, screen real estate is precious. The tag filter panel would dominate the viewport. More importantly, mobile users typically have a clearer intent—they're less likely to be casually exploring. The category landing pages give mobile users a clear path without the overhead of filtering.

section.heading: Content History: A Different Pattern
section.body:
The Content History page breaks from the Case Study/Individual Sample pattern intentionally. It's not a portfolio piece—it's a reference document.

Why It's Different

Content History serves hiring managers who want breadth, not depth. They're asking: "Who have you worked with? What's your range?" A traditional case study format would bury this information in narrative. Instead, Content History uses:

  • A scrolling marquee of brand/talent logos for immediate visual impact
  • Collapsible sections (Copywriting, Publications, Production) to keep the page scannable
  • Card layouts optimized for quick scanning rather than deep reading

Anchor Links in Navigation

Unlike other sections, Content History's nav items link to anchors within a single page (#copywriting, #publications, #production) rather than separate pages. This keeps related content together while still allowing direct links.

section.heading: Responsive Design Decisions
section.body:
The site uses a single breakpoint at 768px. Here's what changes and why:

Feature Desktop (>768px) Mobile (≤768px)
Sidebar Fixed 280px, collapsible Hidden, hamburger menu
Right menu Sticky navigation Hidden
Tag filters Collapsible panel Hidden
Project grid 4 columns Responsive auto-fill
Video hero 80vh height 50vh height
Image magnifier Hover effect Disabled

Philosophy: Mobile isn't a lesser experience—it's a focused one. Features that require hover states (magnifier, tooltips) don't translate to touch. Features that require screen real estate (tag filters, dual navigation) clutter the mobile viewport. By removing these intentionally, mobile users get a cleaner path to content.

section.heading: How to Navigate This Portfolio
section.body:
This section explains how to get the most out of this portfolio, depending on what you're looking for.

Finding Work by Topic (Desktop Only)

1

From the homepage, scroll past the video hero to the project grid.

2

Click Show Filters to expand the tag panel.

3

Select up to 5 tags. Projects update in real-time to show only those matching ALL selected tags.

4

Click any project card to view the full case study or sample.

5

To reset, click Clear all or deselect individual tags.

Note: Tag filters are hidden on mobile devices. Use the sidebar navigation on mobile to browse by category.

Finding Work by Category

1

Use the left sidebar navigation (click the hamburger menu on mobile).

2

Click the expand arrow next to Case Studies or Individual Samples.

3

Select a specific project, or click the section header to view the category landing page with all projects in that category.

Exploring Content History

1

Navigate to Content History from the sidebar.

2

Use the table of contents at the top to jump to a section (Copywriting, Publications, Production).

3

Click View [Section] Projects to expand the details for each category.

4

Scroll through brand cards and mini-cards to see the full range of work.

section.heading: Tag System Reference
section.body:
The tag system organizes work across 21 tags in 4 categories. Here's what each tag indicates:

Design

  • Content Design — Strategic content decisions, UX writing, information architecture
  • Game — Game writing, narrative design, rulebook authoring
  • Systems Design — Designing interconnected content systems

Copy Types

  • UX Writing — Interface copy, microcopy, user-facing strings
  • Technical Writing — Documentation, guides, technical explanations
  • API Documentation — Endpoint references, developer docs
  • Product Writing — Feature documentation, release notes
  • UI/UX — User interface and experience design
  • Marketing — Promotional copy, campaigns, brand messaging
  • Narrative — Story, dialogue, worldbuilding
  • Content Writing — Articles, blogs, long-form content
  • Creative — Fiction, creative non-fiction, experimental formats
  • Trust & Safety — Policy writing, moderation systems, community guidelines

Scope

  • Case Study — Full project context with process and outcomes
  • Writing Sample — Focused demonstration of craft
  • Other Sample — Additional work samples

Secondary Skills

  • GenAI — AI-assisted workflows, prompt engineering, AI tools
  • Prototyping — Interactive prototypes, proof of concepts
  • Change Management — Process transitions, stakeholder alignment
  • Project Management — Timeline, resource, and deliverable coordination
  • People Management — Team leadership, mentoring
  • Cross-functional Collaboration — Working across teams and disciplines
  • Information Architecture — Content structure and organization
  • Content Strategy — Long-term content planning and governance

outcomes.outcome: Created a navigation structure that adapts to different hiring contexts without forcing a professional identity
Designed a tag system with 21 tags across 4 categories for flexible discovery
Built an accessible, responsive experience with intentional feature differences between desktop and mobile
Documented AI-forward development workflow that combines human content decisions with AI implementation speed
Established a maintainable XML-based content system with validation and clear separation of concerns
